product_title: All-new Amazon Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) ‚Äì Our fastest Kindle with auto-adjusting front light, wireless cha
Review Comment:
This is my first Kindle and I was so excited to order. Admittedly, I don‚Äôt know much about the device, as I previously ordered ebooks from their competitors and I use a service for the blind available to me for audio books. I did some research before buying and learned of the accessibility features on the kindle, which is of utmost importance to me. I went with this version (paper-white SE) for the auto adjustable lighting and wireless charging (which I have not used yet, but plan to in the future).

As previously mentioned, I ‚Äúread‚Äù ebooks purchased from other sources and used my iPad which has a ‚Äúread to me‚Äù feature. The kindle offers a VoiceOver option, but it is not as great as the iPad feature. The number one annoyance I have with the Kindle is the non disability friendly Home Screen. WHY is enlargement and font size not accessible on the Home Screen? For someone with vision loss like myself, I can‚Äôt read anything on the main page. This is also the same struggle with the Settings page. Being able to enlarge the screen and change (or bold) the font would be helpful on the Settings screen too.  However, once I get to a book, the accessibility features such as enlarge print, spacing, etc, are acceptable and functional. I would hope products like the Kindle are evaluated and tested for wide consumer use. The blind and low vision community likes to read too, and we can, using technology which I hoped was already integrated on the device.

Moving on from accessibility, the device is lightweight, slim, and easy to carry. It even fit - with a case - in my Lululemon 2L belt bag without issue! I used it without a case for a few weeks and it was easy to hold, though did leave fingerprints on the backing (easily removed with a microfiber towel). Charging time varies, though the battery life is exceptional, having not charged for a week and not even down to half the battery. The screen moves flawlessly- most of the time, though there have been a few instances where the screen moves flawlessly ‚Äúglitched/jumped‚Äù and refreshed. It‚Äôs a split second annoyance, but otherwise it‚Äôs fine almost all of the time. Other than a case with ‚Äúwake‚Äù features, I wish I could touch screen to go from the book cover back to the book without having to push the button on the bottom of the device.

All in all, I am happy to be a new member of the Kindle family, but hope their next model is a little more advanced in accessibility features.  I would purchase again and I wouldn‚Äôt hesitate to gift to a fellow reader.

product_title: All-new Amazon Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) ‚Äì Our fastest Kindle with auto-adjusting front light, wireless cha
Review Title: I really want to love it
Review Comment:
This is my first Kindle. I really like the experience of reading without a light shining in my eyes. When it is too dark to read, I like that I can change the brightness and color temperature of the light. I can take all of my books and audiobooks with me wherever I go. It‚Äôs light so it doesn‚Äôt bother my hands if I read for a long time. I like its size. However, it‚Äôs not perfect. I have some issues with the software and the hardware:

Software:

Clunky: The user interface feels very unpolished, clunky, cluttered, unintuitive, and not user friendly. It‚Äôs a mess. I wish there was a Home Screen with a Kindle app, an Audible app, a documents app, a browser app, a store, and a settings app. Instead, we have one cobbled together monstrosity trying to be all of those things at once. All of my audible books, documents, and kindle books are thrown together and you have to set filters to find things. You can set up collections but you can‚Äôt put audiobooks into collections so they clutter up the ‚Äúuncollected‚Äù folder. The OS just feels lazy, like they didn‚Äôt put much thought or care into the user experience. The swiping gestures also feel unintuitive.
Translation: I am learning a foreign language and most of what I read is in that language. When I come across a word I don‚Äôt know, it‚Äôs nice having the ability to translate that word right on the device. However, every time I need to translate a word, I have to select the word, then Wikipedia will show up then I have to scroll over to translate, then select the language menu, scroll through the list to find the language, select it, and finally I get the translation. I wish I could either get rid of Wikipedia or move it so the first thing that pops up is translation. I want to be able to download the language I am translating for use offline and delete the others from the list of available translation languages. The language detection feature rarely works. I just want to select the word and immediately see what it means.

Hardware:
Power button: Why in the world did they put the power button on the bottom of the device? This has become really bothersome. My pinky naturally rests right where the button is and the screen has turned off many times. It also means I can‚Äôt rest the device on my knee or other surface while reading.
Charging light: It‚Äôs on the bottom next to the USB-C charging port. The issue is that I read before bed so I charge it on my nightstand. The light illuminates the room which is annoying. I‚Äôd rather just have a charging symbol show up on the screen.
Material: The material feels like plastic. I read that the regular Kindle Paperwhite comes with a softer material, which I want. I paid more and feel like I got a downgrade in this area.

Also, I don‚Äôt understand why people are so upset about the lack of buttons. I love that this doesn‚Äôt have buttons.

Overall, there is so much potential in this device but Amazon is holding it back.

product_title: Amazon Echo Pop (newest model), Fits in any room, Our smallest Alexa speaker, Lavender Bloom
Review Comment:
I‚Äôm absolutely loving the Amazon Echo Pop! This little device is a powerhouse in a compact, stylish design. The sound quality is surprisingly rich and clear for its size, delivering great bass and crisp highs, perfect for filling a room with music or getting clear responses when asking questions. The voice recognition is spot-on, and Alexa responds quickly and accurately, whether I‚Äôm asking about the weather, setting reminders, or controlling my smart home devices.

The design is sleek and modern, with vibrant color options that add a pop of personality to any space. It fits perfectly on a shelf, countertop, or desk without taking up too much space, and the sound projection is still impressive. The setup was a breeze, and I love the hands-free convenience it offers.

For a budget-friendly, space-saving smart speaker, the Echo Pop is a fantastic choice. It delivers excellent value with great sound, smart features, and a stylish look. Highly recommend!

product_title: Amazon Echo Pop (newest model), Fits in any room, Our smallest Alexa speaker, Lavender Bloom
Review Title: One of the best smart devices out there!
Review Comment:
The Echo Dot (4th Gen) is a sleek, compact smart speaker with impressive sound for its size. Its spherical design looks modern, and Alexa integration makes controlling smart devices, streaming music, and managing daily tasks a breeze. The microphones are highly responsive, and privacy features like the mute button are a nice touch.

product_title: Amazon Echo Pop (newest model), Fits in any room, Our smallest Alexa speaker, Lavender Bloom
Review Title: Great, hope new features are added
Review Comment:
As a college student, this smart speaker is incredibly helpful for managing my busy schedule. The Echo Pop is more compact and affordable than other Echos. It fits easily in my dorm and is easy to pack when moving between home and school.

Favorite features:
It reads my Google Calendar events to me, and I set personalized wake-up, evening, and unwind routines so that I have the external motivation to do what I need to do at the right times. I also like that I can set multiple timers/reminders without having to go on my phone, so it feels like I have a personal assistant.
I think the audio quality is pretty good as well, and I can pull-up my Spotify playlists (although if you give your playlists some complicated long name, it can be a bit harder). I usually just like to get Alexa to pull up the specific song or artist I feel like listening to at the moment and loop it though.

Improvement:
Because of school I use both Apple & Google products , and it's a bit frustrating not to be able to directly sync Alexa better with the Apple ecosystem. While it reads Google Calendar events, I'd like if Alexa could also see, create, and remind me of my Google Tasks, or do this with Apple Reminders. Currently, you'd have to check the Alexa app for notes that you create with Alexa, and there are no helpful widgets or syncing tools that work well for making this information more accessible.

Also I think the routines feature could be more flexible. Currently, if you want routines to activate at different times on weekdays versus weekends, you have to manually copy and create new routines, but I don't want the extra clutter.

Some other considerations:
Note that the Echo Pop needs to be plugged in at all times to function, so it requires setup every time you move it to a different room. I recommend getting a battery base if you want the flexibility to move it around, such as taking it to a common room or for listening to music while showering.

Overall, it has still added a lot of structure to my days, so I'd recommend it!

product_title: Amazon Echo Pop (newest model), Fits in any room, Our smallest Alexa speaker, Lavender Bloom
Review Comment: This product is perfect for listening to music at low volume, but when you turn up too much, it starts to sound weird. But the product is very good and nice looking. The price was reasonable enough.

product_title: Amazon Echo Pop (newest model), Fits in any room, Our smallest Alexa speaker, Lavender Bloom

product_title: Amazon Echo Pop (newest model), Fits in any room, Our smallest Alexa speaker, Lavender Bloom
Review Title: Amazing Sound at a Low Price
Review Comment:
The Amazon Echo Pop was my first experience with an Alexa device, and I could kick myself for not buying 2 of these at the sale price of just under $23. At that price, these little smart speakers are well worth it. However, at the list price, you might do better to spend another $10 and go for the Echo Dot. Better still, if you can pick up an Echo Gen4 as certified refurbished, then that is quite a good deal at around $50.

Prior to purchasing the Echo Pop, I installed the Alexa App on my iPhone, and during order time, I did the pre-configuration. Upon arrival, the setup was a breeze, and in a matter of just a few minutes I was greeted by a pleasant sounding female voice. The audio quality of this little speaker was amazing. I asked it a few questions, then said ‚ÄúAlexa, play Peaceful Current Radio.‚Äù It was a truly Hi-Fidelity experience, even though it was monophonic. On that station, a great deal of the music is solo acoustic, so stereo , 3D, or surround sound isn‚Äôt necessary to hear the clear and faithful reproduction of a piano, guitar, or cello. The bass from this speaker isn‚Äôt going to rattle the walls, but the little speaker was able to fill my master bedroom with beautiful music, that sounded like the instruments were in the same room.

That should cover the good points about this smart device. I rarely give any product 5 stars, but if I could give it a rating of 4.5 I would, primarily because of what it can do at such a low sell price. There are some issues that you might want to consider if you are looking for a good Echo Device. It is far from perfect. Its smarts are at the low end, and a good Wi-Fi connection is needed if you want a fast response. It can‚Äôt function as a hub, so if you want to control various smart devices in your home, you will likely need an Echo Gen4 or better. It doesn‚Äôt have a 3.5 mm audio jack, so if you want to connect to headphones or external speakers, you will need to use Bluetooth. The Bluetooth connection can be tricky, but once you pair with speakers, it quickly disconnects and reconnects by just turning off the speakers and turning them back on. I also found out that after doing this several times, it began to experience streaming problems, and I had to unplug it and plug it back in to fix the problem.

Bluetooth streaming seems to suffer a bit in fidelity. I paired it with some Logitech Bluetooth computer speakers, and even though it produced stereo sound, the frequency response was not as good, and the stereo separation was weak. Some of this was likely due to the Logitech speakers. They aren‚Äôt exactly the best computer speakers and I am not too fond of the passive radiator design that gives the base an unnatural sound.

I tried a separate GT Bluetooth to 3.5 mm adaptor, which I connected to my retro audio system, and the sound quality was a little better, but I had to crank the volume knob up pretty high. When I connected the Bluetooth adaptor to wired headphones it sounded pretty good, so using Bluetooth headphones seems a good alternative listening method.

One other issue is with the alarm level. I can‚Äôt seem to set it to a level that will override the music, and alert me that it‚Äôs time to take medications or walk the dog. It usually takes me awhile to realize that it is sounding a wake-up. It is loud enough when not playing music, but too low of a level when music is playing.

Overall, it is a very good device, and its small size makes it easy to place in an out of the way location, such as in the kitchen or bathroom. It has great sounding audio that can fill a small room, but not quite good enough to fill a large family or living room. It really shines at playing relaxing music such as from an Internet radio station such as ‚ÄúPeaceful Current Radio,‚Äù or other similar music stations. However, for Rock- and Roll or party music, you will likely want something with a little more punch.

Update:
I just had to do a follow up to my previous review. I caught a sell and picked up another Echo Pop for just under $20. That means I acquired 2 of these for around $45 with tax. They make a great stereo pair. Two speakers are better than one. You get double the sound. This means a great improvement in the base response. With 2 drivers pushing the air, they do a better job. I just tweak the bass response 2 notches, and the treble 1 notch, and these rival the audio quality of my much larger and more expensive JBL studio monitor bookshelf speakers with a 100 watt per channel amplifier pushing them. Of course they can‚Äôt match the power, but 2 of these in a stereo pair can do a pretty good job in my 13 by 13 master bedroom with vaulted ceiling. I‚Äôm considering adding an Echo Sub hidden away under my bed.

Alexa does a much better job at finding my favorite Internet radio stations as well. Siri keeps telling me she can‚Äôt find that in my Apple music library.

I have a database of URLs to over 9000 radio stations. Alexa easily finds most of my favorites such as:
Peaceful current Radio
New Standard WNYC
IPR Studio 1
KTUX FM
KSRY FM
WJIB FM
Caf√© Del Mar Radio
Americana Boogey Radio
Aloha Joe
Quiet Village Radio
WSBZ FM
Smooth Jazz 101
WABE Classical

Just ask Alexa to play any of these, and get ready for a treat.

product_title: Amazon Echo Pop (newest model), Fits in any room, Our smallest Alexa speaker, Lavender Bloom
Review Title: Surprisingly simple for those of us who are new to smart devices & automation
Review Comment:
I found a great Prime Day deal on Kasa smart plugs, and though I already have an app to control them, I decided to see if the Echo Dot they're compatible with was also on sale.  That's when I happened across this Echo Pop for less than half price -- yay Prime Day!  I had seen it before, but I kind of dismissed it, since I have no need for any speakers.  I simply didn't realize that a smart speaker isn't just for playing music and podcasts.  Fortunately, I took a closer look this time and realized this Echo Pop was exactly what I needed!

It was super-easy to set up, thanks in large part to being able to connect it to my Amazon account before I even completed check-out.  Now I can get the weather forecast, set reminders and alarms, and control my smart plugs by just talking to Alexa.  My smart plugs control lamps, fans, and things I want to be sure I always turn off or better yet, unplug, and I can now do all of that by talking to this Echo Pop.  I set up a second Echo Pop up in my bedroom, and I love how it works.  It tells me to get up, turns on my lamp, so I can't turn over and fall back asleep, and pretty much replaces my old style alarm clock.  I feel kinda dumb for not giving the Echo Pop a closer look when it first came out, but then again I'm glad I got it on super sale!

Update: while I'm just loved controlling my smart plugs and devices through with voice with the Echo Pop or through the Alexa app on my phone, I decided I also needed an Echo Show, so I could check my security camera feeds. Big mistake. Although I got a $30 deal through Amazon Warehouse, the Echo Show was a big disappointment, slow to respond and much more tedious to set up thanks to a million options. Plus, it was absolutely loaded with annoying ads. Within 2 hours, I missed the perfect performance and simplicity of my awesome little Echo Pop, so the Echo Show went back in the box for a refund, and I'm back to enjoying life with my Echo Pop.

I've also since purchased a third Echo Pop, this one in Midnight Teal to put in my bathroom.  Sounds like a strange spot, but hear me out.  I'm an older woman who lives alone, and I subscribe to the Alexa "Call for Help" service, and since a slip and fall in the bathroom isn't an impossible situation, I thought it would be smart to make sure a speaker is nearby when I'm in there as well.  Plus, the Midnight Teal is an almost exact match for the color scheme in that room, so clearly this is meant to be.

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Comment:
I bought these earbuds along with 4 other pairs, with the intent of comparing them over a couple weeks and returning all but my favorite.  Here were the results:

Beats Fit Pro - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09JL65GNM?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details
Pros ‚Äì These buds had some great base, and the wingtip gave them a fit that made them refuse to fall out of my ears.  But the best feature?  Physical ‚Äúclicky‚Äù buttons on each one of the buds.  You press in and hear/feel the click, rather than relying on a touchscreen-like feature.  No need to guess if you tapped them once or twice, you will know.
Cons ‚Äì The wingtip gives a very sturdy fit, but not the most comfortable. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend to anyone with smaller ears.  The noise canceling was solid, but nothing special.  And this may be picky, but I didn‚Äôt care for most of the color schemes available.  I prefer my earbuds to be hard to notice, and even the black ones have a bright red letter ‚Äúb‚Äù in the middle.

Beats Studio Buds - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B096SV8SJG?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details
Pros ‚Äì Very comfortable with the same great physically ‚Äúclicky‚Äù buttons as the Beats Fit Pro.  Noise canceling seemed slightly better than average.  Great base.  Classic look.
Cons ‚Äì Tested during a workout, a little bit of sweat had these sliding right out of my ear.  The case for these earbuds also was the flimsiest of any I had tested, with a very weak hinge that I was scared of breaking off within the 2 weeks of using.

Samsung Galaxy Buds Pro - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08MWZHHKP?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details
Pros ‚Äì A neat feature that I noticed only in these earbuds was that it had noise amplification as well as noise cancelation.  With one swipe in the app, the surrounding sound was actually louder and clearer than it would be without the earbuds in.  Great if you are hard of hearing, or just enjoy snooping on conversations out of reach.
Cons ‚Äì Similar to the Beats Studio Buds, these didn‚Äôt stay in during a workout.  They were usable, but every 10 minutes I found myself pushing them back into my ear.  And this is an opinion, but these are the ugliest earbuds out of the bunch.  The shiny black gleam made it look like a large beetle was hanging out in my ear.  No visible brand placement either, which makes them appear cheap and generic rather than the quality Samsung they are.

Samsung Galaxy Buds Live - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09TBM1L3S?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details
Pros ‚Äì Cost effective!  I added these to the test group because of the unique shape, and for that they are worth giving a try.  If you have small ears and do not like the rubber insert that is standard in most other earbuds, these may be perfect for you.
Cons ‚Äì Poor fit for large ears.  These were tested the least of all of the buds, because the fit was so bad for my ear shape that they wouldn‚Äôt stay in if I turned my head too fast.

Bose QuietComfort  - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08C4KWM9T?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details
Pros ‚Äì Bose noise canceling is unmatched.  If your primary use for earbuds is to cancel out that background white noise, this is the pair for you.  The sound quality is great, not too heavy on the base.  The case for the earbuds stood out from the rest as the only one that impressed me.  Felt very study, and I had no worries tossing it into a gym bag or cup holder.  The only case with a button latch to make sure it doesn‚Äôt open accidentally.
Cons ‚Äì This was the most expensive pair of earbuds by a longshot, and there were still some things I felt could be improved.  The rubber inserts had more of a ‚Äúflayed‚Äù shape rather than the ‚Äúrounded‚Äù shape that is standard.  My guess is that this was by design, because the earbuds were also slightly heavier than others and may need that extra in-ear grip.  The flayed shape did make them sturdier, but at the cost of them being uncomfortable in an active situation.  They were also the largest earbuds, and stuck out from the side of my head further than I would have liked.

My favorite?  The beats fit pro!  While I wouldn‚Äôt recommend this pair for everyone, it was perfect for my routine.  My music taste benefits from the boosted base, and the wingtip shape was perfect for any workouts.  The feature that really convinced me was the physical buttons, something that I didn‚Äôt realize how desperately I needed.

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Title: Initial review and comparison to other brands
Review Comment:
I love these earbuds. They feel definitely worth the price and a all around great buy. Giving me exactly what I was looking for.

For years I have used the raycon E55 and some of the features  I loved about raycon was the manual button in the earbuds, excessive bass and great inside-ear fit.
Recently however, raycon has gone the way of the world‚Äî they have put sensors on the earbuds in the place of buttons and Balanced out the audio. So I began my search for new earbuds.

‚ÄîTHE SOUND‚Äî
Both the AirPods, galaxybuds and raycons I have tried tend to be balanced and prioritize giving equal notes to all instruments For a clear and concise sound, But to someone who is not an audiophile it sounds very flat and devoid of the punch that I desire. For me- I want it to be great sounding but also noticeably bass heavy. These Beats Studio buds deliver. The company recognizes that your not using these to analyze a song. These are for the people who like bass and want to feel some gravitas in their ears!

‚ÄîCONNECTIVITY‚Äî
These connect effortlessly to iPhone, as if they were AirPods. It was the single biggest factor that blew me away with these. They are incredibly easy to connect. I cannot speak for android but these work great. They do not have a lot of audio adjustments like Bose but I frankly don‚Äôt need them to. You can easily see the battery state on both buds and the case from a pop up window in your apple home screen whenever opening the case, just like AirPods.

‚ÄîFIT‚Äî
The fit is not as good as the raycon E55 but only by a little bit. They fit snuggly in your ears well enough that they do not fall off when running and working out. Although adjustments might need to be made to them occasionally. (I have small ears, so the fit is review as such)

‚ÄîTHE CONTROLS‚Äî
The controls are simple and straightforward. They are just like what you come to expect from earbuds. Single tap, double tap, triple tap.
The earbuds HAVE AN ACTUAL BUTTON‚Ä¶ which I thought was extinct, I personally hate the sensor buttons because adjusting your earbuds in your ears would trigger the controls.
While these do have a very sensitive physical button‚Äî it is easy to avoid while adjusting with practice.

‚ÄîBATTERY‚Äî
The battery lasts me all day, what more do you want?

‚ÄîRANGE‚Äî
Very good, about 30+ feet

‚ÄîCONS‚Äî
-no MagSafe compatible charging
-fit isn‚Äôt as perfect as some brands but is really good
-if your an audiophile these earbuds are not balanced

Final call-
If you like bass, and hate the sensor controls on most earbuds‚Äî these very well could be the best earbuds you could get. These are on par with earbuds in the 200$ range. And if your anything like me, you will love them! And if not, they might still be worth it to you

‚ÄîUPDATE‚Äî
they have a hard time staying in when working out, and so I had to buy wing tips for these. They automatically have active noise cancellation on when you take them out of the case‚Ä¶ which I personally hate.
And the cases battery is pretty short lived‚Ä¶ only lasts two days generally

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Comment: I have had 2023 rayon earbuds for a while now, but after they started to wear down on me, I got these. I love the sound quality, and the bass is very present, but it doesn‚Äôt drown out any other noises. I have pretty small ears, so the fit is a little loose even after adjusting tip sizes, but the functionality is great! They connect well to my android device, and there is even an app for the ease of use. The battery life is great, and the design is very sleek, while still feeling very high quality and good. Overall, this is a great product to buy, and I would highly recommend!

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Title: An alternative to AirPod Pros? Yes, but with a slight lower quality difference. Worth it? Yes
Review Comment:
I compared these beats with AirPod pros. Both are Apple products.
The beats have a smaller range of volume, the lowest volume is pretty loud for the ‚Äúlowest volume‚Äù. Each level for volume going up is minimal compared to the AirPods. (At around 1/3 of the volume they match volume. AirPods get a lot quieter and ALOT louder, I‚Äôd say 10% louder) The beats are loud enough for me I leave it at 3/4 of volume.
Noise cancellation is really good, some noise filters through in loud environments but it‚Äôs enough when you‚Äôre at the gym and busy places. I experienced noise filtering through when I was in a car with music blasting. So I‚Äôd rate the noise cancellation pretty high.
Pass through, pass through is good. I‚Äôd recommend not having the pass through when there‚Äôs lots of noise cause it‚Äôs good and personally it can get loud. When there‚Äôs a sudden loud noise the earbuds make the same loud noise and it could hurt your ears if you have sensitive hearing.
Cons, when in loud environments if you are on a call the earbuds filter out the noise, and when you speak it filters your voice a bit too which makes it hard for the other person on the other end to hear you. Also the bit about the loud noise with the pass through and sensitive ears is a con for me.
Battery life is really good, lasts me my work day and a bit more, I‚Äôm sure like all batteries that would go down after use but hasn‚Äôt happened to me yet I‚Äôve had it for 2 months now.
Bluetooth, the Bluetooth is pretty strong. You could probably still have a connection a few rooms away in a house before the connection begins to fail. Unlike AirPods when you remove the bud from an ear whatever is playing will not pause unless YOU pause it. This means it‚Äôs constantly connected, when you are within the Bluetooth radius of course. I‚Äôve lost a bud twice but this actually helped me find it, so that‚Äôs a plus. And with these beats you cannot connect another pair to your phone like you can with AirPods. So it‚Äôs only on pair of beats at a time.
I really like the earbuds and I think they are well worth the price, to me they are a barely lesser version of AirPod pros. I‚Äôm considering getting the studio pro‚Äôs over the AirPod max after this experience.

Update 4 months later- The battery life is still very strong, I have had some issues with them disconnecting and reconnecting to my phone and I believe it‚Äôs because when I got my Apple Watch, it must be Confusing the connection between my phone and the watch. Yes, it can be annoying but to me, it‚Äôs still worth it. All really need to do is reconnect with my phone. I don‚Äôt think AirPods Will have this problem. But I‚Äôm not sure. There was one day where the noise cancellation on my right earbud stopped working, but it‚Äôs because I didn‚Äôt have enough battery so I had to charge it after that I had no issues.

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Comment:
I recently got the Beats Studio Buds, and honestly, they‚Äôre a game-changer. First off, the black design is super sleek and fits my style perfectly. When I first put them in, I noticed right away how comfortable they were ‚Äì way better than regular AirPods, at least for me.

The Active Noise Cancelling (ANC) is impressive too. I‚Äôve tested it in some noisy places, and it really cuts down the background sound so I can actually focus on what I‚Äôm listening to. It might not be the same level as over-ear headphones, but for earbuds, it‚Äôs more than enough.

Since they‚Äôre part of the Apple ecosystem, they pair up instantly with my iPhone, and the programmable buttons are a cool feature that makes switching tracks or activating Siri easy. Overall, these are solid earbuds that I‚Äôd totally recommend if you want something comfortable with good sound and a stylish look.

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Comment:
bought these after my airpod pros died on me suddenly. i have been using these beats studio buds for about 6 months and the experience has been inconsistent to say the least. first issue: they fall out of my ears if i do simple things like turn my head or chew. i can barely walk or exercise with them in because they just fall out. i looked online and it seems others have had these issues; people were suggesting swapping the size of the actual ear bud and even wearing them in reverse (with the left bud in the right ear and right bud in left ear). neither if these worked for me. really made me appreciate the airpod design.

it was fairly easy to connect the very first time but every time after that is almost always a pain. if the case is dead but the beats themselves are still charged it‚Äôs like it doesn't recognize that the beats are still working and refuses to connect. even if the case is charged sometimes it just will not recognize that the beats are in range of my phone, even if they're sitting right on top of each other. if it‚Äôs not straight up refusing to connect it‚Äôs disconnecting randomly. if i open my car door - even with the car turned off - the beats automatically disconnect from my phone as if it expects me to connect my phone to carplay. there are many times i have been talking on the phone using my beats and suddenly they will disconnect.

the controls only kind of work. you can use the default preset controls like pressing twice for skipping songs and once for hanging up calls and the like. however you're supposed to be able to customize these controls to in your phone settings but they only work as long as the beats are disconnected. as soon as you put the beats away and disconnect everything goes back to default settings the next time you reconnect. noise cancellation is a joke, it sounds the same as when its on transparent mode or off.

the case feels like cheap plastic. i got a silicone case because i was afraid of scratching it up. not much else to say about it.

the color of the beats are great. i got red and it looks super cool. i think the sound quality is on par with my old airpod pros. when i am on the phone others have not had a problem with not hearing me or me coming across muffled, so that‚Äôs a plus.

overall, these earbuds are nothing special. i got these around the holidays when they were almost half off. glad i didn‚Äôt pay full price for these as they are disappointing at best.

ETA: as of july 2024 i ditched these and bought another pair of airpod pros. literally no regrets.

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Comment: Bought 3 of these for my family and I. 3 different colors. Ease of putting in was great with the different size of gel ear pieces. Functioning has been easy. Quality of sound is great. Bought last year during Black Friday sales, so it was the best value for our money and the quality is wonderful.

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Comment:
After using these for a couple weeks straight, I think it's time to review.
I would like to state upfront that I bought these on sale for $75. I bought the black ones because the pink ones weren't on sale.
Let's start with some pros:
The sound is very good, just about on par with my IEMs. These are definitely catered towards more bassy genres, but in the case of metal, I like being able to hear bass along side lead, and provides some heavy kicks. The physical button instead of just touch is an odd choice, but it works. The package comes with a free trial of Apple music (which I will never use), as well as a tiny usb-c to usb-c charger (so hopefully you have a spare usb-c block), and 3 different sized tips, small, meduim, and large. These have awareness mode, as well as a noise isolation mode. Awareness mode is nice, but noise isolation causes me to have a headache.

Now some cons:
This may be just my ears, but the small tip is too small, and the medium is just big enough to still be pushed out. The body is very smooth, and if you're someone that produces a lot of earwax (like me), it won't stay put and the only thing keeping it in is the tips, meaning you have to keep pushing them back in, and bumping the button. These sit in a very specific position, but don't really like to stay there. Because of the sound mostly being catered towards bass, some leads and vocals can sound a bit muddy at times. By default, the case doesn't have a loop for a string to hold on to and the case is very smooth, so you have to buy a third party case and put it over the stock case just to make it easier to hold on to. These come with an app, and it's very lackluster. No equalizer, there's a find earbuds feature but I'm pretty sure it's not GPS, and you can't mess with settings if the earbuds aren't connected, not to mention: why do my earbuds need to update?!

In conclusion: these are good earbuds and I recommend them, but ONLY IF THEY'RE ON SALE.
These are 100% worth the $75 I spent on them, but NO WAY ARE THEY WORTH THE $150 RETAIL PRICE TAG.

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Comment: Great sound in a compact design. I've had three pairs of the powerbeats pro and continue to love those, but the ear clip always gave me trouble with sunglasses and/or baseball hat. I got a bit of a headache from the side pressure after a while. Still, I love the powerbeats. These buds sounds just as good, though I don't feel the transparency mode is all that quality, as it changes the output sound/quality in my ear but doesn't make outside conversations or ambient hearing any easier. I still have to pause or take one out. My biggest gripe is with the case. I love the size and feel of the case itself, though it doesn't accommodate all sizes of the rubber earbud tips without impacting the ability to charge effectively. I have smaller ears and I wanted to use the tips from my powerbeats pro and the studio buds case doesn't charge properly when you change up the tips. That's unfortunate and super annoying because the space is there, just the engineering isn't. It's a poor design feature and definitely surprising considering I'm trying to use tips that are native to Beats. Overall, great earbuds, quality sound, just not sure the case engineers should get that raise this Christmas.

product_title: Beats Studio Buds - True Wireless Noise Cancelling Earbuds - Compatible with Apple & Android, Built-in Microphone, IPX4 Ratin
Review Title: Pretty good. Not GREAT, but not bad.
Review Comment:
Whenever I see something with a 4-star review, it usually means it‚Äôs a solid product but there‚Äôs something (or somethings) keeping it out of 5-star range.

For me, these are a perfect example of that. They‚Äôre small (good), not terribly obtrusive (only some out-of-ear-stick-out, tho your experience may vary), the sound has some solid bass which is helpful for the gym (where I tested these out), the sound overall is clear (download some equalizer apps to play with the sound itself), and they stayed in my ear well. I don‚Äôt know much about soundstage or whatever, but the sound itself is clear, bass is nice and strong, and you can hear even the subtle nuances like the shifting of a hand on guitar strings clearly enough without being disturbed. That, to me, is the sign of a good earbud.

The transparency mode and noise canceling modes were alright. But that‚Äôs just it, they‚Äôre alright. Granted, the AirPod Pros have a higher price tag, so they do the ANC and Transparency mode much better. So it‚Äôs understandable that these would do the same, but on just the slightest bit of a lower level.

I‚Äôm also spoiled bc the Airpod Pros have wireless charging. These DO have USB C, but the lack of wireless charging is a small thing, really. There‚Äôs something about being able to toss these on a charging pad and leaving them there to charge that‚Äôs just so satisfying. Also, was not a fan of how the case just doesn‚Äôt have that ‚Äúpremium‚Äù feel. The matte finish is nice, tho I would have liked a little more weight in the case lid, but at this point, these are such little (and I mean LITTLE) things that really, it‚Äôs not a dealbreaker.

My only thing is the amount they stick out. I‚Äôm sorry, but they do look a little‚Ä¶funny, the way they sort of stick out just a bit so that the ‚Äúb‚Äù logo is upright. They don‚Äôt stick out a LOT, but juuuuust enough that when you look in the mirror, you‚Äôll see a vertical line where the physical button (which I have managed to press on accident a couple of times while adjusting the bud) sticks out. Also, I had a little difficulty getting them to stay in, but that‚Äôs beyond pretty much anyone‚Äôs control.

These get that 4th star because of just how they are a solid enough product worth the purchase. They don‚Äôt do any one thing particularly well, but there are just enough teeny things for me that I wouldn‚Äôt say these are the best I‚Äôve ever used. (For comparison, the Jabra 75t gets the equivalent of a 4.3 rating‚Ä¶the hear-through is amazing and their app really helps boost functionality).

For me, these are SOLID gym earbuds. They play music loudly, clearly enough, and the bass is strong enough for me that I can drown out whatever annoying other music is playing outside. They fit and stay relatively well. For the price tag, you get some good bang for the buck. You could do worse, but at this range, depending on if you want to pitch in a few more, you could also do better.

product_title: Amazon Echo Show 5 (newest model), Smart display with 2x the bass and clearer sound, Glacier White
Review Comment: I purchased this Echo Show to interface with a Blink Camera.  I had never used an Alexa enabled device and have found it is much more useful and fun than I expected.  This Echo Show sounds great when playing music and can provide a lot of information.  Setup was a little more complicated than expected and had to spend about 30 minutes before I got the hang of it.  Only down side of this Echo Show is that it does not have battery backup.  Always has to be plugged in to work.  Would buy again.

product_title: Amazon Echo Show 5 (newest model), Smart display with 2x the bass and clearer sound, Glacier White
Review Title: First Echo screen wasn't working correctly, this Echo Works Great.
Review Comment: This is the second Echo and it works great. The first Echo the screen would go totally off and she was hard to wake up at that point. I let Amazon know and this one arrived the next day. I still have the old one but do not trust it. Excellent Customer Service.

product_title: Amazon Echo Show 5 (newest model), Smart display with 2x the bass and clearer sound, Glacier White
Review Title: A Compact Smart Display with Impressive Sound Quality
Review Comment:
I've been using the Amazon Echo Show 5 (3rd Gen, 2023 release) for a few weeks now, and I am thoroughly impressed with its performance. The Echo Show 5 has always been a reliable smart display, but this latest version truly steps up the game, especially in terms of sound quality.

**Sound Quality:**
One of the standout features of this Echo Show is its upgraded sound system. With 2x the bass and clearer sound than its predecessors, the audio quality is surprisingly robust for such a compact device. Whether I'm listening to music, catching up on the news, or watching videos, the sound is rich and immersive. It's perfect for smaller rooms, like the kitchen or bedroom, where you want good audio without the need for a larger speaker.

**Display and Design:**
The 5.5-inch screen is sharp and vibrant, making it great for watching short clips, checking the weather, or making video calls. The compact design fits easily on any shelf or counter, and the Charcoal color gives it a sleek, modern look that blends well with any decor. The screen's adaptive brightness is a nice touch, adjusting automatically based on the room's lighting.

**Smart Features and Alexa Integration:**
As expected from an Echo device, the Alexa integration is seamless. Voice commands are picked up easily, even from across the room, and the responses are quick and accurate. I use it to control my smart home devices, set reminders, and even follow along with recipes. The new smart display features also make it easier to see and control multiple smart home devices at once, which is a huge plus for someone like me who has a lot of them.

**Privacy and Security:**
Amazon has included a physical shutter for the camera, which provides peace of mind for those who are concerned about privacy. There's also a mic/camera off button, which is easy to use and effectively disables both the microphone and camera.

**Overall Performance:**
The Echo Show 5 (3rd Gen) is a fantastic addition to any smart home setup. It offers a great balance of audio quality, smart features, and privacy controls. Whether you're new to smart displays or looking to upgrade, this device is definitely worth considering. It's small but mighty, and I find myself using it more than I expected for everything from checking my calendar to watching cooking videos.

product_title: Amazon Echo Show 5 (newest model), Smart display with 2x the bass and clearer sound, Glacier White
Review Title: Failed in Less Than One Year BUT Amazozn Tech Support to the Rescue!
Review Comment:
Update to below original review:  Amazon tech support reached out to me to help fix this problem.  So, I have increased from 2 stars to 4 stars.  Still not 5 stars because there is a device problem somewhere.  In addition, I believe the Echo Dot (no screen) is a better device - it "hears" better and has better sound.  If you run into the Echo Show going into zombie mode (where it appears to be rebooting, powering off, and repeating a doom loop over and over), try the following:

- Put it into factory default mode by holding Mute and Volume Down for 30 seconds until you see three dots appear on the screen.  It should enter setup at this point and if it works after setting it up, good.

- If you get through the setup process and parts of it repeat over and over, cycle power for one minute and try again.  This second step was necessary for me but it works now.

Thanks, Amazon support!

product_title: Amazon Echo Show 5 (newest model), Smart display with 2x the bass and clearer sound, Glacier White
Review Title: Could be great, but has some really annoying issues
Review Comment:
We had a first generation Echo Show in our kitchen which died recently so I ordered this as a replacement, not realizing how small it is.  It's about the size of a standard alarm clock, which is too small for our kitchen.  Rather than returning it, though, I decided to keep it for the bedside table, which appears to be what it was made for.  I then ordered an Echo Show 8 for the kitchen, which is a much better size for there.

Anyway, having this on the nightstand is nice, because not only does it function as a clock, but I can ask it about the weather, the news, etc. in the morning.  The bluetooth speaker has very good sound for its size.  Overall, it's a great purchase.  Except...

It's got a couple of really annoying flaws that severely limit its usefulness.  Ugh.  Amazon, I really hope you're listening here.  At least the first of these should be fixable with a simple software update.  The second, I'm not as sure if it's a software problem or a hardware issue, but I hope that it will at least be updated by the next model.  While I'm probably not going to return this one, I can't see myself buying another one of these (or recommending it to other people) until these issues get fixed.

So, first problem... Using it as a bluetooth speaker.  I like to play music from Apple Music on my iPad, and I was hoping to use this for that.  Yes you *can* link your Apple Music account directly into the Echo Show, but that's got a couple of flaws ‚Äì first, you can't browse, you have to tell Alexa what to play, and second, if you've got your own music that you've uploaded to Apple Music because it's not in the main Apple Music library (or another app entirely), there is as far as I can tell no way to access it.  So, using the Echo Show as a bluetooth speaker it is.  Except...

Once you pair your iPad with Alexa, it will very loudly announce that it's connected.  "Now connected to Matt's iPad" it says very loudly.  If I had it connected previously and I start using my iPad after leaving it sit for a while (say, I was listening the night before and I pick up my iPad in the morning to glance at the news), even if I'm not playing audio, it will make the same announcement again (which, totally unexpected like that, gives me a good jump scare).  Disconnect the iPad and it makes a loud notification sound (for a while it was saying "Disconnected from Matt's iPad" but I seem to have managed to at least turn that off... I'm not even sure how).  It does the same if I connect and disconnect my phone.

I don't want this.  It's super annoying.  I've tried every way that I can find to turn these bluetooth announcements off, and I can't do it.  I've searched the internet and found lots of other people complaining of the same issue, but Amazon hasn't fixed it.  Some of those have suggested turning off notifications as the solution, but I've tried that (even going as far as power cycling my Echo Show to make it reboot), and I *still* get the bluetooth announcements.  They just won't go away.

So, first thing this needs before I'll give it a good rating... Amazon, please do away with these bluetooth announcements, or at least make it possible for me to disable them.  Honestly, I'd prefer not to have to completely disable notifications to do it (there's no fine grain control over notifications, it's either all on or all off, which is a problem itself), but if that's how it has to be whatever.  Just get rid of these unnecessary and annoying bluetooth announcements.

Then, there's what is actually a much bigger problem, but may require a hardware update to fix... The auto-dimming.

So, in theory, I like and want the auto-dimming feature.  I don't want this to be at full brightness all night while the room is dark.  In the dark it goes very dim, but that makes it readable in the dark without being annoying or a distraction from sleep.  That's good.

Based on how this performs, though, I have to assume that the light sensor that controls the auto-dimming is on the front and very directionally focused.  It doesn't pick up on ambient light at all.

So if I turn on the bedside lamp, which happens to be located behind the Echo Show 5 on my table?  It doesn't pick up on it, it still thinks the room is dark, and it keeps the display so dim that it's totally unreadable in the lamp light.  I use my bedside lamp a lot when I'm in the bedroom, so that is a HUGE problem.  Even if I have both the overhead light and the bedside lamp on and the screen is bright, the moment I turn the overhead light off (but leave the bedside lamp on), it goes so dark as to be unreadable.

But even when I'm using the overhead light...  If I even happen to stand or sit so that I'm positioned between the overhead light and the Echo Show unit, it dims the display.  Not nearly as dim as it goes in the dark room or with the bedside lamp, but still dim enough to make it significantly harder to read.

So basically, I can only read the screen easily with the room brightly lit or totally dark, with light directly pointed at the unit or no light at all.  Anywhere in between and it becomes unreadable.  Of course I could "fix" this problem by turning auto-dimming off entirely, but then it would be brightly lit all through the night.  Which I don't want either.  Right now the only setting for this is either on or off, no in-between, no adjusting the sensitivity, nothing.

So Amazon, I don't know if this means that you need more light sensors on the unit than you currently have (maybe one facing the back of the unit as well), or if it's just a software tweak to make it more (or less?  I don't even know) sensitive, but SOMETHING needs to be done about this.  A screen that I can't read isn't useful to me.

Oh, and finally, this is more minor but what is up with the white power cord on my black/"charcoal" device?  I didn't buy a white Echo Show because I didn't want a white Echo Show.  The power cord should match the device.  Way to cheap-out, Amazon.

Fix these problems and I'll feel much better about the Echo Show 5 and happily recommend it to others as a bedside device.  With these issues, though, I'm sorry, but I can't recommend it.

product_title: Amazon Echo Show 5 (newest model), Smart display with 2x the bass and clearer sound, Glacier White
Review Title: Helps With Organizing Life - One Drawback
Review Comment:
I have three of these. They are generally okay. I won't review "Alexa" here, just the device itself.

Set up is kind of tedious. I still don't know what "skills" provide. Otherwise the device works fine.

Now the drawback (minus 1 star): It doesn't really support installing "apps" in the traditional sense. They are simply features. If the feature doesn't exist, you can't install it. For example, there is no YouTube functionality. Instead, when you ask Alexa to go to YouTube you'll get Amazon Silk opened to YouTube. Amazon Silk is just a web-browser and YouTube is tedious to use from a browser on such a small device.

Oh, and Amazon Silk itself is a hot piece of garbage.

On the positive side, I love that I can just add things to my shopping list as soon as I think of them. I love that I can control lights remotely so I can tell Alexa to turn lights on and off before I come home, or while I'm away.

I do not regret my purchase. I expect the software will improve more over time.

product_title: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
Review Comment:
The Roku Express 4K+ is an outstanding streaming device that delivers crisp 4K and HDR content with ease. The setup was incredibly simple‚Äîjust plug it in, connect to Wi-Fi, and start streaming. The Roku Voice Remote is a great addition, allowing easy voice control for searching, volume, and playback.

I love the access to free and live TV options, which adds even more value to the device. Streaming performance is fast and smooth with no buffering issues, and the interface is intuitive.

If you're looking for an affordable, high-quality 4K streaming experience, the Roku Express 4K+ is an excellent choice. Highly recommend!

product_title: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
Review Title: Roku Express 4K+: A Fantastic Streaming Experience for Me!
Review Comment:
After using the Roku Express 4K+ for a few weeks, I can confidently say I‚Äôm really happy with my decision. I was looking for a way to upgrade my streaming setup and get 4K quality without spending too much, and this device has delivered in all the areas that matter most to me.

Pros:
Amazing Picture Quality:
The 4K HDR support on this Roku is impressive. Watching movies and shows in 4K has been a noticeable upgrade in picture quality. Colors are vibrant, and details are crisp. Even older content looks better, and I‚Äôve really enjoyed seeing my favorite shows in a new light with such clear, sharp visuals.

Simple Setup and Easy to Use:
Setting up the Roku Express 4K+ was so easy. I had it up and running in just a few minutes, thanks to the clear instructions on the screen. The interface is straightforward, and navigating through different apps and channels is super simple. Everything I need is right there, and I don‚Äôt have to spend time hunting for what I want.

Roku Voice Remote is a Game-Changer:
The Roku Voice Remote is one of my favorite features. I love how easy it is to search for shows or movies just by speaking into the remote. It works really well, and I don‚Äôt have to scroll through endless menus anymore. Plus, it controls both the Roku and my TV‚Äôs volume and power, so I only need one remote.

Great Free and Live TV Options:
I‚Äôve been really enjoying the free channels and live TV access. The Roku Channel offers a solid variety of free movies and shows, and there are a lot of live news, sports, and entertainment channels available, which means I don‚Äôt need an extra subscription to watch live content.

Tons of Streaming Options:
Having access to all the major streaming services like Netflix, Hulu, Disney+, and Prime Video is perfect for me. I‚Äôm able to find whatever I‚Äôm in the mood for, and the device handles everything smoothly. The app interface is clean and easy to navigate, which makes switching between different streaming services hassle-free.

Cons:
Not for Gaming:
While this device is great for streaming, it‚Äôs not built for gaming. If I wanted to play any serious games, this wouldn‚Äôt be the right choice, but that‚Äôs not something I‚Äôm using it for, so it doesn‚Äôt bother me.

Audio isn‚Äôt Top-Tier:
The sound quality is decent but not exceptional. The built-in audio is fine for everyday use, but it doesn‚Äôt blow me away, especially with the 4K visuals. I‚Äôm considering adding a soundbar to get better sound to match the picture quality, but for now, I‚Äôm still happy with how it performs overall.

No Ethernet Port:
The lack of an Ethernet port is a bit of a downside for me since I prefer wired connections for more stable streaming. I‚Äôm using Wi-Fi, which works just fine, but I do notice occasional fluctuations in speed. Not a deal-breaker for me, but it's something I‚Äôve noticed.

Final Thoughts:
The Roku Express 4K+ has been an excellent addition to my setup. The picture quality is fantastic, the voice remote is incredibly convenient, and the setup was quick and easy. The free and live TV options are a nice bonus, and I‚Äôve found myself exploring a lot of new content because of it. While the sound quality and lack of an Ethernet port are small inconveniences, they haven‚Äôt detracted from my overall enjoyment of the device.

product_title: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
Review Comment:
Our old TV just got a reprieve.  After doing some research, we bought this Roku Express 4K+ streaming player and found it works quite well.  We have hooked it up to an old Samsung 22" TV (model code LT22B350ND/ZA) which was made in 2013.  Received it within a few days of ordering it and it took about 20 minutes to get it working.
Ease of use: Follow the included instructions.  I plugged it into our power strip rather than the TV USB port since I heard that there were issues related to that (one report of fire, some issues with inadequate power, etc.).  Remote takes a little time getting used to - I haven't figured out what all the buttons do and I still haven't figured out how to slave the remote to adjust TV sound.  I can imagine that will make my life easier because I won't need to use the TV remote for anything else except for changing the input source and doing some TV fine tuning.  Volume adjust/mute buttons are on the side of the remote which was an issue for a few people, but I'm OK with it.  From past reviews, sounds like the remote is not very durable but that remains to be seen.
Speed: quite responsive - no complaints
Appearance: The wireless receiver is quite unobtrusive.  This Roku comes with a mounting strip so you can stick it where you want it.  I just parked it on the TV base without the strip.
Battery life and the rest:  remains to be seen but for a gadget that cost less than $40, we're satisfied.  So much so that we will get another for our living room TV - it's a few years younger but we expect the Netflix and Prime Video software for it to eventually outdate.  One thing that bothers me is that you have to sign up for a Roku account which means giving out your credit card info.  I still have misgivings about doing that being the closet Luddite that I am.

product_title: Roku Express 4K+ | Roku Streaming Device 4K/HDR, Roku Voice Remote, Free & Live TV
Review Comment:
I hope Roku doesn‚Äôt get too excited that I bought this and go out and celebrate with champagne. I actually have a ten year old Roku 3 stuffed somewhere deep in a closet or something and it would have worked just fine.  I already have 99.9% of what this does built into my high-end projection TV. The only reason I bought it is that the makers of my TV won‚Äôt pay the Netflix licensing fee so I can‚Äôt watch the very few things I want from that service on their projector. So the one and only thing this will ever be used for is that purpose. I know most people are here wanting to read reviews with specs and opinions about the picture quality and things like that but if I made just one person‚Äôs life better by letting them know for thirty bucks (twenty if HD is good enough for you) you can make your TV or projector think it is compatible with that streaming service.  And it does work.  And maybe I‚Äôll pick up some additional content too, it looks like Roku is going big into the content creation business.

PICTURE QUALITY

If you got this far, don‚Äôt have high expectations from any review of the picture quality, there is no answer. It is what it is, 4k is 4k, how it looks on your TV will depend mostly on your TV, and to some degree your internet provider, but in any case the Roku box isn‚Äôt going to have a very direct influence on what you see.

QUIRKS

Oddly, Roku still uses line-of-sight infrared for their remote control while most remotes I am used to these days are RF. That means the receiver has to be located where the remote can ‚Äúsee‚Äù it. With today‚Äôs ultra-thin TV‚Äôs that can be a challenge because the sensor is located on the side not the face of the receiver, so for it to be ‚Äúseen‚Äù would mean to try to stick the adhesive strip on an edge of a TV that can be less than a quarter of an inch, or even rounded.  As if that‚Äôs not bad enough in my case I am using it with a projection TV and my projector is located behind our seating area. The only thing I could do is to choose the best location I could which still means I have to turn around and point the remote backwards at the projection TV. This is 2024, why hasn‚Äôt Roku kept up with the real world?

Also in the same category is that the four direct access buttons can‚Äôt be re-programmed. I know over the years they have changes those buttons as different TV sources come and go in popularity but what if one of the services (I‚Äôm thinking Disney) is something we would never use? That wastes 25% of the available buttons. Yet something we watch every day (I‚Äôm thinking YouTube) is not possible to assign to that unused button. Again Roku, this is 2024, even ten years ago I could assign my own favorites to a A and a B button, why aren‚Äôt you thinking of such things?

DEALBREAKERS

While I used the word dealbreaker I‚Äôll temper that by saying I am keeping this product, not because I want to but because if I want to watch Netflix on my projector I have to. But if that were not the case it would go right back to them right now. It took me three hours to set it up and I am highly technical, I set most things in in minutes usually without reading instructions. If you have a desire to bring back technology for the 1980‚Äôs this is the device for you. The setup is maddening. Whether or not you want to use their power button and volume control with your TV, that‚Äôs not your choice, they force that decision on you and there is absolutely no way to get past that first setup screen after it hooks up with your wifi. They give you a list of TV brands. If yours isn‚Äôt on the list, sorry, there is no way of saying so or skipping that option. Your only option is something they call Advanced (it‚Äôs not) which makes the assumption that your TV‚Äôs remote is infrared (mine is RF). Roku never heard of RF so you are dead in the water at that point. There is a CEC option but that is way technical and I don‚Äôt have to discuss it here. So I went online and not surprisingly they don‚Äôt say a word about it. I went to the user forums and other people have the same frustration but there was a lot of ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know or useless suggestions with no way to give feedback that they were useless.  I finally did come up with a way to confuse the device and move on but not after a good part of my afternoon was gone.

YES NO MAYBE

My answer is that the HD unit at ten bucks less is so much the same that most people will never be able to tell the difference on 95% of what they watch. But if you are a perfectionist and ten bucks more isn‚Äôt a dealbreaker than you might as well splurge.  What about all the other models?  My opinion is your return on investment is very little with them, you get some nice but not necessary features but the price premium is far too much. Overall I would say this model gives you the best bang for your buck but that doesn‚Äôt mean I can endorse poor engineering and product design. They are resting on their laurels and shouldn‚Äôt be congratulated for that and anything more than an average rating is too high.
